content.description: Start on the arête with a left on a great jug and right on a good side pull. Get feet, move up and rock up onto the great ledgey foot and then go to the top. Short but fun.
content.protection: Pads, recommend putting a pad on the rock to the right of the arête as well.
content.location: About 200-300 feet up from Frog Legs. On the 'Master of None' boulder.

content.description:
A tricky problem with smooth slopers. Although short, it packs quite a few moves. The arete is smooth granite, which is friendly on your hands and atypical for Clough. 

  Start sitting with your hands below the lip in a pocket and on a sloper sidepull or hold right of the pocket. Figure out your feet and pull up. Traverse the slopey lip (it is bad!) until you can get to the left arete and throw to the peak of the boulder, or use some serious beta trickery (toehooks, heelhooks, leg-bars, and more toehooks) to get to the top. 

youtube.com/watch?v=wxi4wOc…
content.protection: 2 pads. The landing is mostly flat, but the last move could fling you into a rock or some roots.
content.location: Right in the woods before the orange gate, on the same boulder as Frog Legs V3.

content.description: Middle problem on the 'Master of None' boulder. Sit start on a left sidepull and right on the big flat ledgey hold. Get feet and pull up to good holds. Up to the top.
content.location: Middle of the 'Master of None' boulder

content.description: Sit start on a good left side pull and small right crimp. Pull off the ground and then work up on good holds.
content.location: Left most problem on the Master of None boulder

content.description: Start on left side pull just below the left arête and right pinch or any crimp in the seam, find feet and work up the arête to the jug at the top.
content.location: About 100 feet in right of the gazebo.

content.description: Sit start under the arete with a good sidepull and a good hold on the lip. Pull on and set a heelhook and traverse the sloping lip leftwards around the corner over a slanting landing. Once around the corner utilize some interesting meathooks and keep traversing till you reach buckets and can top out. A fun and pumpy traverse.
content.protection: Three or four pads and a spotter. The landing isn't too bad, but it can still be nerve racking.
content.location: Take a right at the gazebo and go into the woods on the trail next to the gate. From here you will see the lowball "Perry Problem". Walk past that problem up the hill towards the huge 30 foot scoop project. If you look left you will see a short overhang and a nice looking clean arete. The front face looks almost like Pacman.

content.description: There is a large cluster of small boulders behind the gazebo. It looks like a few fun lines can be done including a unique "French Press" like slab. There is also a cliff band behind the cluster of talus which holds some very unique features, cracks and rock quality. The landings tend to drop down a hillside though.
